sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: This chapter describes the overall behavior of the user interface. Description of the various component parts—the menu bar, panes and various diagrams— is in separate chapters.

sect1.title: Overview of the Window

textobject.para: A display of the &argouml; window, showing at the top the menu bar, in the main area four sub-windows and at the bottom a status bar. The four sub-windows are arranged two by two, and named, clockwise from top left as: navigator pane, editing pane, details pane and to-do pane. at the top of the editing pane is a horizontal tool bar.

sect1.para: At the top of screen is a menu bar described in . The bulk of the window comprises four sub-windows or panes. Clockwise from top left these are the navigator pane (see ), editing pane (see ), details pane (see ) and to-do pane (see ). At the top of the editing pane is a tool bar. An overview of the panes is given in . Finally at the bottom of the window is a status bar described in .

sect1.title: General Mouse Behavior in &argouml;
sect1.para: &argouml; assumes a two button mouse. We will refer to the buttons as &button1; and &button2;. &Button1; is the leftmost button on a right-handed mouse, and sometimes referred to as the select button. &Button2; is the rightmost button on a right-handed mouse, and is sometimes referred to as the adjust button.

sect2.title: &Button1; Click
sect2.para: This action is generally used to select an item for subsequent operations. If the item is an artifact in the navigation pane or the editing pane it will be highlighted.

&Button1; click over the name of any diagram artifact will cause the diagram to be selected and displayed in the editing pane. Its details will also be displayed in the details pane.

&Button1; click over the name of any artifact other than a diagram in the main area of the navigation pane will cause it to be selected, and its details shown in the details pane. If the artifact is part of a diagram currently displayed in the editing pane, it will be highlighted there.

note.para: If the artifact is part of a diagram other than that currently displayed in the Editing Pane, there will be no change of diagram in the Editing Pane.

sect3.title: Within the Editing Pane
sect3.para: In the tool bar of the editing pane, &button1; click is used to select the next tool for adding artifacts to the diagram (but only once—see double clicking for adding multiple artifacts). Adding to the diagram is achieved by moving the mouse to the editing area and clicking again.

sect3.title: Within the Menu Bar
sect3.para: Over a top level drop down menu this will expose the menu.
Over a menu entry this will invoke the action of the menu.
Within menu dialog boxes this will generally select a text item, and invoke a button action.

sect2.title: &Button1; Double Click
sect2.para: In general this action is identical to a single click except, when it is used with the editing pane tool bar, in the to-do pane, or in dialog boxes (which are mostly associated with menu actions).

sect3.title: Within the Editing Pane
sect3.para: When used on the tool bar with a tool to add an artifact, the selected artifact will be added multiple times to the drawing area, once for each further button click, until the tool is again selected or another tool chosen.

sect3.title: Within the To-Do Pane
sect3.para: Within the to-do pane this will select the diagram for the associated artifact in the editing pane and highlight the artifact that is affected using an appropriate clarifier (the artifact may be highlighted, underlined with a wavy line or surrounded by a colored box as appropriate).

sect3.title: Within Dialog Boxes
sect3.para: Within dialog boxes this will cause an action associated with a text item to be invoked. For example double clicking on a filename during the Open Project… dialog will cause the file to be selected and opened.

sect3.title: Within the Editing Pane
sect3.para: When adding an artifact using the toolbar, &button1; motion can generally be used to define the size of the new artifact. Its dimensions (line ends, diagonal corners of a rectangular artifact etc) are defined by &button1; down and &button1; up.
Over graphical artifacts &button1; motion will move the artifact to a new position. Graphical artifacts that are selected show handles, and these can be used for re-sizing.
Some artifacts (e.g. actor, class) show special handles at the sides, top and bottom, which can be dragged to form types of relationship with other artifacts.

Where the artifact is some form of connector between other items, &button1; motion other than at a handle will cause a new handle to be created, allowing the connector to be articulated at that point. Such new handles can be removed by moving them to the end of the connector.

sect3.title: Within the Menu Bar
sect3.para: Moving over a top level menu, or a sub-menu will cause that menu to be exposed.
If the button is released (thereby completing a click) over a menu entry that entry will be invoked.

sect2.title: &Button2; Actions
sect2.para: When used over text items in the the navigation or details panes, or graphical artifacts in the editing pane, this will display a context dependent pop-up menu.
If the item or artifact has not yet been selected it will also be selected.
In general there are no &button2; actions associated with menus.

sect2.title: &Button2; Double Click
sect2.para: This has no effect other than that of &button2; single click.

sect2.title: &Button2; Motion
sect2.para: This is used to select items in a context sensitive menu popped up by use of &button2; click.

sect3.title: Within Lists
sect3.para: This behavior applies where there is a list of things that may be selected. This includes various dialog boxes, and the to-do pane, where there is a list of to-do items to be selected.
Similarly the CONTROL key with &button1; is used to add individual items to the current selection. Where Ctrl-&button1; is used on an item already selected, that item is removed from the selection.

sect3.title: Within Diagrams
sect3.para: This behavior applies to diagrams within the editing pane.

Where selections are to be made, the SHIFT key is used to with &button1; to add unselected artifacts to the current selection. Where an artifact is already selected, it is removed from the current selection.
The CONTROL key is effective where selected artifacts are being moved. Using the CONTROL key will cause them to be moved with the broom (see ).

sect1.title: General Information About Panes
sect1.para: The four sub-windows of the main &argouml; window are called panes. Clockwise from top left these are the navigator pane (see ), editing pane (see ), details pane (see ) and to-do pane (see ). At the top the editing pane is a tool bar.

sect2.title: Re-sizing Panes
sect2.para: You can re-size panes by dragging on the divider bars between them.

sect2.title: Looking at Different Diagrams Simultaneously
sect2.para: You can spawn a copy of the editing pane by double-clicking on the As Diagram tab at the bottom of the pane. It will then show as an individual window and you can put it where you will on the screen.
The same effect is achievable with the tabs of the details pane.

note.para: There is no equivalent function for the navigation or to-do panes.

sect2.title: Reducing the Number of Panes Visible
sect2.para: This function is not implemented directly. However you can spawn a pane (see ) and maximize this to be the whole window, which achieves the same thing.

sect1.title: The status bar
sect1.para: The status bar is at the very bottom of the &argouml; window and is used to display short advisory messages.

In the current release of &argouml; the only messages are those associated with &button1; motion in the editing pane. Where &button1; is held down over a 2-D artifact, the message Move object(s) will appear. Where &button1; is held down over a connector, the message Add a point will appear.

note.para: &argouml; is a system in development, and occasionally other messages will appear. In particular clicking on the background on the editing pane will cause a message of the form [<n>] to appear where <n> is a small integer.
